src:
Izlet v srednji vek
V dolini sv. Janeza spet zaživela Žička kartuzija; sprehod med ohranjenimi gotskimi kapelami in skozi ladjo sv. Janeza Krstnika za vsako družino.
02 Nov 2019, 06:16 by Jaroslav Jankovič



Žička kartuzija, skrita med gozdovi



Leseni ganki varovalnega obzidja s stolpiči



Prepišna gotska okna brez barvitih vitražev pričajo o bogati preteklosti.



Molilna gotska kapelica, zadaj obrambni zid s stolpom FOTOgrafije: Jaroslav Jankovič



Ostanki gotske cerkve sv. Janeza Krstnika


Lepi jesenski dnevi so kot nalašč za družinski izlet. V Žiče pri Slovenskih Konjicah, denimo. Iz Ljubljane bomo z avtomobilom potrebovali eno uro, Žiče so namreč od prestolnice oddaljene točno 100 kilometrov. Gre za starodavno naselje, a naš cilj še pet kilometrov oddaljena Žička kartuzija, ustanovljena okoli leta 1160. Eden najstarejših samostanov na Slovenskem, starejši je le stiški samostan cistercijanov iz leta 1132, spada med naše najfascinantnejše srednjeveške spomenike.


Ostanki gotske cerkve sv. Janeza Krstnika

Če smo bolj radovedne popotniške sorte, bomo proti kartuziji z avtoceste proti Mariboru zavili že v Dramljah in nadaljevali pot po lokalni cesti skozi vasi in prek gozdnatih gričev, kak kilometer bo tudi makadama. Ostanki samostana se nam bodo skozi gozd na dlani prikazali naravnost filmsko. Lahko pa uberemo udobnejšo pot in nadaljujemo po avtocesti do Tepanj in od tam nazaj udobneje skozi Žiče in pri Škednju pod avtocesto proti kartuziji.


Prepišna gotska okna brez barvitih vitražev pričajo o bogati preteklosti.

Ko smo stopili iz avta, nas je zajela tišina ob belih zidovih samostana, rahlo je žuborel le potoček, listje krošenj pa je porumenelo. Hoja po peščeni poti čez mostiček do glavnega vhoda, kjer se nam visoko proti nebu postavi zidovje veličastne gotske cerkve sv. Janeza Krstnika, deluje kot časovni stroj, ki te v trenutku prestavi daleč v srednji vek. Strehe ni več, le zidovi in pokončna prepišna okna brez barvitih vitražev pričajo o bogati preteklosti.Težko si predstavljamo, kako so takrat živeli kartuzijani in ljudje naokoli, a vendarle, občutek daje slutiti, da so dali od sebe vso energijo, da bi se približali najvišjemu. Na desni smo opazili obrambno stavbo z lesenim gankom, na levi podolgovato poslopje z vhodom v Otokarjevo klet, kjer konjiška klet Zlati grič hrani peneča se vina.


Leseni ganki varovalnega obzidja s stolpiči

Malo naprej preseneti križni hodnik, ki pa je zelo nizek in daje občutek, da so morali biti kartuzijani pred stoletji nekaj manjši od nas. V povprečju so bili menda srednjeveški ljudje nižji od nas za več kot 20 centimetrov.Kot pravijo zgodovinski viri, so kartuzijo gradili po pravilih reda: običajno je imela dve stavbi, zgornjo in spodnjo. Spodnja naj bi stala na lokaciji današnje cerkve v bližnjem, kilometer oddaljenem Špitaliču, na mestu današnje cerkve, kjer naj bi imeli kartuzijani svoj hospic, kamor so najrevnejši okoliški prebivalci prihajali po hrano, obleko in zdravila.Danes ohranjeno obzidje in vse stavbe znotraj so gradili postopoma, današnjo obliko je kartuzija začela dobivati v 15. in 16. stoletju, v času turških vpadov. Turki so večkrat poskušali vdreti v kartuzijo, in to jim je uspelo 3. marca 1531, ko so ubili priorja Andreja in nekaj menihov.
Žički patri so obiskovalce in goste sprejemali praviloma zunaj obzidja. Nastanili so jih v Gastužu, še danes eni najstarejših delujočih gostiln v Evropi iz leta 1467.
Kako vitalna in vplivna je bila Žička kartuzija v takratni Evropi, govorijo viri, da je knjižnica žičkih kartuzijanov štela nič manj kot 2000 na roke napisanih knjig. Skoraj dve desetletji (od 1391. do 1410.) pa je prav Žička kartuzija zaradi razkola v Katoliški cerkvi prevzela vodilno vlogo v politiki kartuzijanov. Prav v tej magični dolini sv. Janeza se je odločalo o življenju in delu vseh kartuzijanskih samostanov. Nekaj kartuzijanov iz Žič je bilo papeških svetovalcev.Ker pa so bili kontemplativni red, se je njihova zgodba v dolini sv. Janeza končala leta 1782, ko je cesar Jožef II. v duhu razsvetljenskih reform ukinil vrsto samostanov po državi, tudi Žičko kartuzijo.
Žička kartuzija je imela tudi mlin in ribnike, ki pa danes niso več ohranjeni.
Samostan je počasi ostal prazen, podrli so nekaj celic patrov in material prodali, po velikem požaru v Konjicah so ljudje iz samostana vozili material za nadomestno gradnjo. Danes je lično obnovljen, v njem sta poleg muzeja urejena lončarski in slikarski atelje.

A trip to the Middle Ages
In the valley of St. John of Zice Carthusian Monastery again alive; a walk between the preserved Gothic chapels and through the nave of St. John the Baptist for every family.
02 Nov 2019, 06:16 by Jaroslav Jankovic



Zice Carthusian Monastery hidden between forests



Wooden porches of guard walls with columns



Overpriced Gothic windows without colorful stained glass show a rich past.



Gothic Prayer Chapel, rear defensive wall with tower PHOTO: Jaroslav Jankovič



The remains of the Gothic church of St. Of John the Baptist


The beautiful autumn days are perfect for a family outing. In Zice near Slovenske Konjice, for example. It will take us an hour from Ljubljana by car, because Zice is 100 kilometers from the capital. It is an ancient settlement, but our goal is another five kilometers distant Zice Carthusian Monastery, founded around 1160. One of the oldest monasteries in Slovenia, older than just the Cistercian monastery of Styria from 1132, is one of our most fascinating medieval monuments.


The remains of the Gothic church of St. Of John the Baptist

If we are a more curious traveler, we will already turn towards the Carthusian Monastery from Maribor to Dramlje and continue our journey along the local road through the villages and through the wooded hills, what a kilometer the gravel will be. The remains of the monastery will appear straight through the woods in the palm of our hands. However, we can take a more comfortable route and continue along the highway to Tepanj and from there back more comfortably through Žiče and at Škednje under the motorway towards the Carthusian Monastery.


Overpriced Gothic windows without colorful stained glass show a rich past.

As we got out of the car, we were silenced by the white walls of the monastery, only a small creek murmured and the foliage of the canopy turned yellow. Walking along the sandy path over the bridge to the main entrance, where the walls of the magnificent Gothic church of St. Martin are placed high up in the sky. John the Baptist, acts as a time machine that in a moment moves you far into the Middle Ages. The roofs are gone, only the walls and upright windows without colorful stained-glass windows testify to the rich past. It is hard to imagine how the Carthusians and the people around lived at the time, but the feeling is that they gave themselves all the energy to get closer the highest. On the right we see a defensive building with a wooden porch, on the left an elongated building with an entrance to the Otokar cellar, where the Golden Hill horse cellar holds sparkling wines.


Wooden porches of guard walls with columns

A little further along, the cross aisle, which is very low and gives the feeling that the Carthusians must have been slightly smaller than us centuries ago. On average, medieval people were thought to be less than 20 inches below us. According to historical sources, the charterhouse was built according to the rules of the order: it usually had two buildings, the upper and the lower. The lower one is supposed to have stood at the site of today's church in the nearby, one kilometer away Spitalic, at the site of the present church, where the Carthusians were supposed to have their own hospice, where the poorest surrounding people came for food, clothing and medicine. gradually, the current form began to take shape in the 15th and 16th centuries, during the Turkish invasions. The Turks repeatedly attempted to invade the Carthusian Monastery, and they succeeded on March 3, 1531, killing Prior Andrew and some monks.
Zice patrias generally received visitors and guests outside the walls. They were established in Gastuz, today one of the oldest operating inns in Europe in 1467.
How vital and influential the Zice Carthusian Monastery was in Europe at the time, sources say that the Zice Carthusian Library numbered no less than 2,000 at the hands of books written. For almost two decades (from 1391 to 1410), it was precisely the Zice Carthusian Monastery that, due to the schism in the Catholic Church, took the lead in the politics of the Carthusians. It is in this magical valley of St. John made decisions about the life and work of all Carthusian monasteries. Several Carthusians from Zice were papal advisers. However, because they were a contemplative order, their story in the valley of Sts. John ended in 1782, when Emperor Joseph II. abolished a series of monasteries around the country, including the Zice Carthusian Monastery, in the spirit of the Enlightenment reforms.
The Zice Carthusian Monastery also had a mill and ponds, which are no longer preserved today.
The monastery slowly remained empty, a few cells of patras were torn down and material sold, and after a large fire in Konjice, people from the monastery were driving material for replacement construction. Today, it has been personally renovated and houses a pottery and painting studio beside the museum.
